revision.text:
{{Infobox Settlement |official_name = Budslau |native_name = Будслаў |native_name_lang = be |nick_name = |other_name = {{lang|pl|Budsław}} |image_skyline = Будслав.jpg |imagesize = |image_flag = |image_seal = |pushpin_map = Belarus |map_caption = Location of Budslau, shown within the [[Minsk Voblast]] |subdivision_type = [[Countries of the world|Country]]
[[Subdivisions of Belarus|Subdivision]] |subdivision_name = [[Belarus]]
[[Minsk Region]] |leader_title = |leader_name = |established_title = |established_date = |area_magnitude = |area_total_km2 = |area_land_km2 = |area_water_km2 = |population_as_of = |population_note = |population_total = |population_metro = |population_density_km2 = |timezone = [[Eastern European Time|EET]] |utc_offset = +3 |timezone_DST = |utc_offset_DST = |coordinates = {{coord|54|47|0|N|27|27|0|E|region:PL_type:city|display=inline,title}} |elevation_m = 172 |postal_code = 222510 |area_code = +375 1797 |blank_name = |blank_info = |website = |footnotes = }} '''Budslau''' ({{lang-be|Будслаў}}, {{lang-pl|Budsław}}) is a village in [[Belarus]]. It is located in the [[Myadzyel Raion]] of [[Minsk Region]], 150 km north of the [[Capital (political)|capital]] [[Minsk]]. The village developed itself around the National Sanctuary of the Mother of God of Budslau, [[Church of the Assumption of the Blessed Virgin Mary, Budslav|Minor Basilica]] consecrated in 1643. == External links == * [http://www.catholic.by/2/en/belarus/sanctuarium/100262-budslau.html The National Sanctuary of the Mother of God in Budslau] [[Category:Villages in Belarus]] [[Category:Populated places in Minsk Region]] [[Category:Vilnius Voivodeship]] [[Category:Vilna Governorate]] [[Category:Wilno Voivodeship (1926–39)]] {{Belarus-stub}}

page.title: Embassy of the United States, Warsaw

revision.text:
[[File:USA_Embassy_in_Warsaw_Poland.jpg|thumb|The U.S. embassy in Warsaw in 2009, viewed from [[Ujazdów Avenue]]]] [[File:U.S. Embassy Warsaw Seal.png|thumb|Seal of the Embassy of the United States, Warsaw]] The '''United States Embassy in Poland''' is situated on [[Ujazdów Avenue]] in [[Warsaw]], Poland.
During [[World War II]], the United States kept relations with the [[Polish government-in-exile]]. The U.S. Embassy in Warsaw was reestablished on July 5, 1945, the same day on which the embassy in London was closed. Ambassador [[Arthur Bliss Lane]] was in charge of the embassy pending his presentation of credentials.<ref>{{Cite web|title = A Guide to the United States' History of Recognition, Diplomatic, and Consular Relations, by Country, since 1776: Poland|url = https://history.state.gov/countries/poland|website = history.state.gov|access-date = 2016-01-31}}</ref>
The United States also maintains a consulate in [[Kraków]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = U.S. Consulate General Krakow {{!}} U.S. Embassy & Consulate in Poland|url = https://pl.usembassy.gov/embassy-consulate/krakow/|website = U.S. Embassy & Consulate in Poland|access-date = 2016-02-02|language = en-US}}</ref>
== See also == * [[United States Ambassador to Poland]]
== References == <references />
== External links == * https://pl.usembassy.gov/
{{US diplomatic missions}} {{Diplomatic missions in Poland}} {{coord|52.2246|N|21.0238|E|region:PL_type:landmark|display=title}}
[[Category:Diplomatic missions of the United States|Warsaw]] [[Category:Diplomatic missions in Warsaw|United States]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Warsaw]] [[Category:Poland–United States relations]]
{{poland-stub}} {{US-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox language |name=Fanji |altname=Bafanji |nativename=''Chuufi'' |region=[[Cameroon]] |ethnicity=Bafanji |speakers=17,000 |date=2008 |ref=e18 |familycolor=Niger-Congo |fam2=[[Atlantic–Congo]] |fam3=[[Benue–Congo]] |fam4=[[Southern Bantoid]] |fam5=[[Grassfields languages|Grassfields]] |fam6=[[Eastern Grassfields languages|Eastern Grassfields (Mbam–Nkam)]] |fam7=[[Nun languages|Nun]] |iso3=bfj |glotto=bafa1249 |glottorefname=Bafanji }} The '''Fanji language''', ''Chuufi'' (''Nchufie''), is a [[Grassfields languages|Grassfields language]] and the language of the '''Bafanji''' people in the [[Northwest Region (Cameroon)|Northwest Region]] of [[Cameroon]].{{Harvcoltxt|Silverman|1995|p=57}} There are approximately 17,000 speakers. The language has a rich system of [[tone (linguistics)|tonal]] [[morphology (linguistics)|morphology]], including [[reduplication]] involving [[adjectives]]. ==Phonology== === Consonants === {| class="IPA wikitable" style="text-align: center" |- |+{{Harvcoltxt|Silverman|1995|p=58}} ! colspan="2" | ! [[Labial consonant|Labial]] ! [[Alveolar consonant|Alveolar]] ! [[Postalveolar consonant|Post-
alveolar]] ! [[Palatal consonant|Palatal]] ! [[Velar consonant|Velar]] |- ! colspan="2" |[[Nasal consonant|Nasal]] | m | n | | ɲ | ŋ |- ! rowspan="3" |[[Stop consonant|Stop]] ! Plain | p | t | t͡ʃ | c͡ç | k |- ! [[aspiration (linguistics)|Aspirated]] | pʰ | tʰ | t͡ʃʰ | c͡çʰ | kʰ |- ! [[Prenasalised consonant|Prenasalised]]{{r|footnote1|group=decimal}} | mb | nd | nd͡ʒ | ɲɟ | ŋɡ |- ! rowspan="2" |[[Fricative consonant|Fricative]] ! Voiceless | f | s | ʃ | ç | |- ! Voiced | | z | | | ɣ |- ! rowspan="2" |[[Approximant consonant|Approximant]] ! [[central consonant|Central]] | | | | j | w |- ! [[lateral consonant|Lateral]] | | l | | ʎ | |} {{reflist |group=decimal |refs= The prenasalised stops may also be considered voiced with redundant prenasalisation. }} ==References== {{reflist}} *{{citation |last=Silverman |first=Daniel |year=1995 |title=Optional, conditional, and obligatory prenasalization in Bafanji |journal=Journal of West African Languages |volume=25 |pages=57–62 }} {{Languages of Cameroon}} {{Grassfields Bantu languages}} [[Category:Languages of Cameroon]] [[Category:Grassfields Bantu languages]] {{Cameroon-stub}} {{nigerCongo-lang-stub}}

revision.comment: Replacing Flag_of_North_Ossetian_ASSR.svg with [[File:Flag_of_the_North_Ossetian_ASSR.svg]] (by [[commons:User:CommonsDelinker|CommonsDelinker]] because: [[:c:COM:FR|File renamed]]: To harmonize the filename.).
New political grouping in the Council of Europe. Details are somewhat scarce as of yet.
revision.text:
The '''Free Democrats Group''' is a political group in the [[Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe]] (PACE). The group came together in June 2017<ref>[http://www.assembly.coe.int/committee/BUR/2017/BUR008E.pdf Synopsis on the meeting held in Strasbourg on 30 June 2017], Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe, accessed 13 October 2017.</ref> and was formally recognized by PACE on September 4, 2017.<ref>[http://assembly.coe.int/nw/xml/News/News-View-EN.asp?newsid=6757&lang=2&cat=13 The Free Democrats Group: a new political group within PACE], Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe, accessed 13 October 2017.</ref>
==References== <references/>
{{Europe-poli-stub}} [[Category:Council of Europe]] [[Category:Pan-European political parties]]

revision.text:
{{more footnotes|date=June 2014}} {{Infobox deity | type = Voodoo | name = Maman Brigitte | god_of = Goddess of life, death, justice, motherhood, fertility, cemeteries, crosses, gravestones, women, souls of deceased relatives, obscenities, passion | member_of = [[Ghede]] | image = VeveBrigitte.svg | alt = | caption = [[Veve]] for Maman Brigitte | other_names = Grandma Brigitte, Manman, Maman Brijit, Grann (or Gran) Brigitte, Brigitte, Manman Brijit | abode = Voodoo [[underworld]] | mantra = [[Haitian Vodou drumming#Loa and nanchons|Banda]] | animals = Black rooster, horse | symbol = Rum, hot peppers, fire, gravestones, crosses | tree = Elm, weeping willow | color = Purple, black, green | consort = [[Baron Samedi]] | offspring = [[Ghede Nibo]] (adopted) | gender = Female | Christian_equivalent = [[Saint Brigid of Ireland|St. Brigid]]
[[Mary Magdalene]] | equivalent1_type = Celtic | equivalent1 = [[Brigid]] }} '''Maman Brigitte''' ([[English Language|English]]: ''Mother Brigitte'') also written '''Gran Brigitte, Grann Brigitte''', '''Manman''', '''Manman Brigit''', and '''Maman Brijit''', is a death [[loa]] and the wife of [[Baron Samedi]] in [[Haitian Vodou|Vodou]]. She drinks rum infused with hot peppers and is symbolized by a black rooster. Like Samedi and the [[Ghede]], she is foul-mouthed.[http://www.meta-religion.com/World_Religions/Voodoo/ancestors.htm "The Ancestral Lwa - Baron, Maman Brigitte, And The Lwa Ghede"], Meta Religion. She is also the adoptive mother of [[Ghede Nibo]]. Brigitte is the only [[White people|white]] Voodoo god, having her origins in [[Ireland]], and not in [[Africa]] or [[Haiti]] like other loa.Max Sparber, [http://www.happyhooligan.co/2014/10/irish-american-halloween-irish-voodoo/ "Irish-American Halloween: Irish Voodoo"], The Happy Hooligan, 20 October 2014. She is described having brown or red-gold hair and emerald green eyes, and is associated with [[Brigid]], the [[Celtic deities|Celtic goddess]] of healing and life. She protects gravestones in cemeteries if they are properly marked with a cross. Horses, weeping willows, fire, and elm trees are considered sacred to her. A New World loa, Maman Brigitte is syncretized with various saints, including [[St. Brigit|Saint]] [[Brigid#Brigid and Saint Brigid|Brigid]] and [[Mary Magdalene]]. == References == {{Reflist}} *[[Laennec Hurbon]], ''[[Voodoo: Search for the Spirit]]'', "[[Abrams Discoveries]]" series. [[Harry N. Abrams, Inc.]] (1995) *Shannon R. Turlington, ''The Complete Idiot's Guide To Voodoo''. [[Alpha Books]]. (2001) {{Afro-American Religions}} [[Category:Voodoo goddesses]] [[Category:African mythology]] [[Category:Death goddesses]] [[Category:Fire goddesses]] [[Category:Irish goddesses]] {{Haiti-stub}} {{Africa-myth-stub}}

{{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} {{Infobox saint | name = Marinette (Vodou) | feast_day = | venerated_in = [[Haitian Vodou]], [[Folk Catholicism]] | image = | imagesize = | caption = | birth_date = | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | titles = | canonized_date = | canonized_place = | canonized_by = | attributes = Black pig, black roosters, owls, black, red, peppers, werewolves | patronage = Fire | major_shrine = | suppressed_date = | issues = }} '''Marinette''' is a [[loa]] of power and violence in [[Haitian Vodou]]. In her [[Petro loa|petro]] form she is called ''Marinette Bras Cheche'' (Marinette of the Dry Arms) or ''Marinette Pied Cheche'' (Marinette of the Dry Feet) suggesting that she is [[skeleton|skeletal]].
She is believed to be the [[Mambo (Voodoo)|Mambo]] who sacrificed the black pig at the culmination of the start of the first [[Haitian Revolution]]. While she is feared and tends to ride those she [[Spirit possession|possesses]] violently, she can also be seen as one who frees her people from bondage.
Marinette is represented by a [[screech owl]] and is often seen as the protector of [[werewolves]]. Her [[Catholic]] counterpart is the [[Anima Sola]] ([[Purgatory|Forsaken Soul]]) who can either free one from bondage or drag you back. Her colors are black and deep blood red. Her offerings are black [[pig]]s and black [[rooster]]s plucked alive.
Mambo Marinette is not cruel. She only gets cruel in possession, when people burn animals or humans. Her colors are red and black. She likes Salvia, black pepper, lavender and sweets.
==In popular culture==
Marinette is a main character in Rem Oscuro's book ''I am the Dark''.
FLÏRT, a band from Hamburg, Germany, refers to Marinette in the song "Marinette of the Dry Feet".
Marinette the main antagonist in the DC Comics Series Ragman - Cry of the Dead.
Marinette, or Her Lady of the Dry Arms, appears in "The Bruja" by Michael Molisani.
{{Afro-American Religions}}
[[Category:Voodoo goddesses]] [[Category:African mythology]]
{{Haiti-stub}} {{Africa-myth-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox recurring event | name = Mikser Festival | logo = | image = | imagesize = 300px | caption = | genre = Lectures, Exhibitions, Competitions, Concerts, Films | date = | frequency = Annually | location = [[Belgrade]], Serbia | first = | founder_name = [[Maja Vidaković Lalić]] | prev = <!-- [[previous event]] --> | next = <!-- [[next event]] --> | participants = International and local artists, designers, architects, musicians, and gaming companies | attendance = 75,000 | area = | budget = | patron = | organised = | people = over 1,000 participants | member = | website = http://festival.mikser.rs | footnotes = }}
The Mikser Festival is an annual exhibition promoting design, architecture, urban planning, new technologies, art, music, and communications in [[Serbia]].<ref name="blic.rs">{{cite web|url=https://zena.blic.rs/puls-poznatih/maja-vidakovic-lalic-mikser-je-doveo-strance/xq1fe25|title=Maja Vidaković -Lalić: MIKSER je doveo strance|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://winestyle.rs/2010/maja-vidakovic-lalic/|title=Maja Vidaković Lalić - Wine Style|date=29 June 2010|publisher=}}</ref> It was founded in 2006 by architect [[Maja Vidaković Lalić]]. The festival invites international and local experts from the fields of creative industries.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://festival.mikser.rs/en/about-mikser-house/ |title=About Mikser House - Mikser Festival 2017 |publisher=Festival.mikser.rs |date= |accessdate=2018-06-06}}</ref> In addition to lectures, competitions, and workshops, there are exhibits, concerts, films and theater plays.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://festival.mikser.rs/en/complete-programme/ |title=Complete Programme - Mikser Festival 2017 |publisher=Festival.mikser.rs |date= |accessdate=2018-06-06}}</ref> ==About== The festival occurs once a year in [[Belgrade]] at the end of May or the beginning of June, and usually lasts about 4 to 7 days. The first show was held at the "Žitomlina" silo in the [[Dorćol]] area of [[Belgrade]].<ref name="blic.rs"/> Since then, the festival regularly took place in the once derelict industrial zone of [[Savamala]], helping revitalize the [[Belgrade]] neighborhood, before returning to [[Dorćol]] in 2017.<ref name="auto">{{cite web|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=VL-aDgAAQBAJ&pg=PA132&lpg=PA132&dq=mikser+festival+2008&source=bl&ots=fn_ZVJNUv8&sig=r4OCin_0-nn7HSYuCEeZtKlzdq0&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjV26nN06PbAhWrq1kKHXrXA9Q4ChDoAQgoMAA#v=onepage&q=mikser+festival+2008&f=false|title=The Impact of Artists on Contemporary Urban Development in Europe|first1=Monika|last1=Murzyn-Kupisz|first2=Jarosław|last2=Działek|date=4 April 2017|publisher=Springer|via=Google Books}}</ref>
In 2010, the festival attracted 40,000 visitors and in 2017, the numbers had risen to 75,000.<ref name="auto"/>
The Misker Festival is part of the Mikser umbrella organization, which includes the Mikser House, a gallery and cultural space located in the [[Savamala]] neighborhood.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2014/12/17/world/europe/hip-belgrade-resilient-capital/index.html|title=Hip Belgrade: Resilient capital finds new energy to rebuild once again|first=Paula Newton,|last=CNN|publisher=}}</ref> The umbrella group also comprises the reMiks Studio, Mikser TV, the Mikser Organization, the Miksalište Refugee Center, the Mikser Café and the Balkan Design store.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scen.uns.ac.rs/?p=20460|title=SCENLAB RAZGOVORI / SEZONA 5: ŠTA RADIM I ŠTA MI SE DOGAĐA, Maja Vidaković Lalić, arhitekta i kreativni direktor – SCEN|website=www.scen.uns.ac.rs}}</ref>
The Mikser Festival also sometimes coordinates with other events. In 2006, it's Ghost Project exhibit was shown at [[Belgrade Design Week]]. A multimedia installation, Ghost Project first focused on local unrealized projects in industrial design and since 2011 has evolved into a competition for international designers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.designaustria.at/posts/3078-mikser-festival-international-design-competition-ghost-project-2017|title=Mikser Festival: International Design Competition »Ghost Project 2017« - designaustria|website=www.designaustria.at}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://mikser-remiks.blogspot.com/search/label/Ghost%2Bproject|title=Mikser|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://festival.mikser.rs/en/project/ghost-project-2017-new-nomads/ |title=Exhibition: Ghost Project 2017 - The new nomads - Mikser Festival 2017 |publisher=Festival.mikser.rs |date= |accessdate=2018-06-06}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://inhabitat.com/designcompetitions/ghost-project-international-design-competition-2011/|title=Ghost Project International Design Competition 2011 - Design Competitions|website=inhabitat.com}}</ref>
==Highlights== The main theme of the 2011 festival was the promotion of workshops, new technologies, and experimentation, as well as commemorating the 20 year anniversary of the break-up of [[Yugoslavia]]. Musicians who had been popular before the break-up were invited to perform.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.last.fm/festival/1929925+Mikser+festival+2011|title=Mikser festival 2011 at Žitomlin magacini (Beograd) on 25 May 2011 - Last.fm|website=Last.fm}}</ref> [[Greg Wilson (DJ)|Greg Wilson]], [[John Tejada]], JD Twitch and JG Wilkes, from the British club scene, also made appearances. In 2011, [[Maja Vidaković Lalić|Lalić]] launched The Young Balkan Designers competition as part of the Mikser Festival.<ref name="blic.rs"/> Aimed at local industrial designers,<ref name="core77.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.core77.com/posts/17774/Young-Balkan-Designers-2011-Call-for-Entries-Competition|title=Young Balkan Designers 2011: Call for Entries Competition - Core77|website=Core77}}</ref> the first competition was judged by designer [[Konstantin Grcic]] and [[Maja Vidaković Lalić]].<ref name="core77.com"/> Winners had their work shown at design events such as the [[Milan Furniture Fair]] and Vienna Design Week.
In 2014, the Misker Festival focused on the [[Savamala]] neighbourhood, in a bid to continue its revitalization. 40 urban planners from around the world were invited to discuss possibilities for renewal. Austrian choreographer William Dorner performed a dance recital with the goal of inspiring local residents to protect their city.<ref name="mojasrbija.rs">{{cite web|url=http://mojasrbija.rs/wp/mikser-festival-2014/|title=Mikser festival 2014 - Moja Srbija|date=4 June 2014|publisher=}}</ref> Three Swiss artists exhibited a multimedia installation featuring video footage of [[Savamala]] and other urban neighborhoods. A conference and workshops were also held with Dutch designer Renne Ramakers and British architect [[Jeremy Till]] in attendance.<ref name="mojasrbija.rs"/>
The 2017 festival concentrated on the themes of migration, education on the move, the city, and the making of culture. The topics were addressed through design, the visual arts, cinema and music, as well as the lecture series "Mikser Talks". About 50 local and international experts spoke about the planning of cities, architecture, design, social sciences, information technologies, and communications.<ref name="blic.rs1">{{cite web|url=https://www.blic.rs/vesti/beograd/umetnost-arhitektura-zabava-otvoren-deveti-mikser-festival-na-dorcolu/4y0gkp7|title=UMETNOST, ARHITEKTURA, ZABAVA Otvoren deveti MIKSER FESTIVAL na Dorćolu|publisher=}}</ref> Representatives from the [[Imperial College]] in [[London]] gave a presentation about sustainable urban planning. <ref name="novosti.rs">{{cite web|url=http://www.novosti.rs/vesti/kultura.71.html:666897-Sutra-pocinje-deveti-Mikser-festival|title=Sutra počinje deveti Mikser festival|website=www.novosti.rs}}</ref> Additionally, the festival hosted a bazaar with home-made clothes and food stands,<ref name="blic.rs1"/> and also invited the gaming company [[Nordeus]], which organized workshops for Serbian youth.<ref name="novosti.rs"/> Concerts were given by musicians Aleksandar Sedlar Bogoev, Marko Luis and the Lola Klasik String Orchestra, among others.<ref name="blic.rs1"/> New in 2017, was a creative camp aimed at solving social problems through technology.<ref name="novosti.rs"/>
==See also== * [[Belgrade Design Week]] * [[Maja Vidaković Lalić]] ==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * http://festival.mikser.rs ==References==
[[Category:International conferences]] [[Category:Events in Belgrade]] [[Category:Design awards]] [[Category:Industrial design awards]] [[Category:Festivals in Serbia]] [[Category:Serbian designers]] [[Category:Design events]] [[Category:June events]] [[Category:May events]] [[Category:Spring (season) events]] [[Category:Annual events in Serbia]] [[Category:Spring (season) events in Serbia]] [[Category:Festivals in Former Yugoslavia]]

revision.text:
{{Expand Slovenian|Popkorn (roman)|topic=culture|date=September 2011}} {{Infobox book | name = Popkorn | title_orig = | translator = | image = | image_caption = | author = | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = {{flag|Slovenia}} | language = [[Slovenian language|Slovenian]] | series = | subject = | genre = | publisher = | pub_date = | english_pub_date = | media_type = | pages = | isbn = | oclc = | dewey = | congress = | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''Popkorn''''' is a novel by [[Slovenia]]n author [[Andrej E. Skubic]]. It was first published in 2006.
==See also== *[[List of Slovenian novels]]

{{Slovenia-stub}} {{Europe-novel-stub}} {{2000s-novel-stub}}

{{Infobox Christian denomination |name = '''Evangelical Protestantism in Albania''' |image = Logo of Albanian Evangelical Brotherhood (VUSH).jpg |imagewidth = |alt = |caption = |abbreviation = VUSH |main_classification = Evangelical Protestantism |theology = Biblicist |governance = Autonomous independent churches and organizations, but voluntarily cooperative |founder = The Apostle Paul, Gjerasim Qiriazi<ref>The Christian evangelization of Albania was apostolic, since the Apostle Paul visited the territories of modern Albania (cf. Romans 15:19). Gjerasim Qiriazi is considered the first Albanian preacher in the modern Protestant tradition.</ref> |founded_date = ca. A.D. 60; 1890 |founded_place = Illyricum (Romans 15:19); Manastir (present-day Bitola, Macedonia) (later in Korça, Albania) |separated_from = |parent = |merger = |separations = |fellowships = Baptist, Brethren, Assemblies of God, non-denominational groups, etc. |associations = Various regional associations |area = Albania, with partnerships in Kosovo and other Albanian regions |hospitals = |nursing homes = |aid = |congregations = approx. 200 |members = approx. 10000 |ministers = |primary_schools = |secondary_schools = |tax_status = |tertiary = |publication = |other_names = Albanian Evangelical Churches |footnotes = }} {{Albanians}} '''Evangelical Protestantism''' is one of five officially recognized faiths in [[Albania]].<ref>FLETORJA ZYRTARE E REPUBLIKËS SË SHQIPËRISË. Nr. 34, 07 prill 2011.</ref> It is a [[Christian]] faith that views [[Jesus Christ]] as its founder and head, and the [[Bible]] (especially the [[New Testament]]) as its written authority. [[Evangelical]] [[Protestants]] in Albania numbered approximately 8,000 in 1998.<ref name="Christianity Today">{{cite web | url=http://www.ctlibrary.com/ct/1998/july13/8t819c.html | title=First Protestant Church Dedicated | publisher=Christianity Today Library }}</ref> The International Religious Freedom Report of 2007 reported 189 different Protestant associations and groups.<ref name="US Dept of State">{{cite web |url=https://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2007/90160.htm |title=International Religious Freedom Report 2007: Albania|publisher=www.state.gov |work=US Dept. of State/Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights, and Labor |date=2006-09-15 |accessdate=2010-05-13}}</ref> Unlike other official religions in Albania, Evangelical Protestants are not organized under a [[hierarchy]] with an official head, but operate autonomously in separate churches or organizations bearing different denominational or non-denominational names. Most, but not all Evangelical/Protestant groups are members of the Albania's Evangelical Brotherhood (VUSH), a cooperative organization which views itself as existing as "an instrument of blessing … with the purpose of promoting unity amongst the churches, representing every local church with dignity, and promoting evangelism."<ref>http://www.vush.org (official website)</ref>
==History== On August 26, 1816, [[Robert Pinkerton]] wrote the [[British and Foreign Bible Society|British and Foreign and Bible Society]] to encourage them to translate the New Testament into [[Albanian language|Albanian]].<ref>The Thirteenth Annual Report of the British and Foreign Bible Society, 1817, p. 93-94.</ref> [[Cyrus Hamlin]] reported in 1857 that Albanians were applying to his Protestant seminary.<ref>ABCFM Annual Report, 1857, Boston, p. 61.</ref> The first documented Albanian Protestant was [[Kostandin Kristoforidhi]], who left his native Orthodox faith and converted to Protestantism on his own while comparing Orthodox, Roman Catholic and Protestant theological texts. He joined the Protestant Church of Smyrna in 1856 or 1857, and was sent to Istanbul for theological training.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=|first="Smyrna Station". : 20–21. 1857.|date=1857|title=Smyrna Station|url=|journal=The Gospel in Turkey: being the third annual report of the Turkish Missions-Aid Society|volume=|pages=20-21|via=}}</ref>
In [[Bitola|Monastir]], [[Gjerasim Qiriazi]] also converted to Protestantism ca. 1876–1877, and united with the multi-ethnic Protestant church there. The first two known Albanian Protestant-Evangelical churches were both established by Gjerasim Qiriazi, first in Monastir in 1884 and later in [[Korça]] in 1890 (both cities then part of the Ottoman Empire).<ref>{{Cite book|title=Lëvizja Protestant ndër shqiptarët, 1816–1908|last=Hosaflook|first=David|publisher=Universiteti i Tiranës (disertacion)|year=2017|isbn=|location=Tirana|pages=216–219, 240–245}}</ref>
In April 1890, Gjerasim Qiriazi was ordained as the first Albanian evangelist and preacher by the [[American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions]] in the board's annual meeting help in Monastir.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Lëvizja Protestant ndër shqiptarët, 1816–1908|last=Hosaflook|first=David|publisher=Universiteti i Tiranës|year=2017|isbn=|location=Tirana|pages=240–242}}</ref> The second church among Albanians was opened in [[Korça]]. Qiriazi was also the head of one of the first national societies within Albania, named “The Evangelical Brotherhood”. As a result, Gjerasim Qiriazi is considered as the father of the Albanian Protestant Church.<ref name="Kisha Protestante">{{cite web | url=http://www.kishaprotestante.net/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=230&Itemid=116&lang=en | title=Development of the Protestant church amongst Albanians | publisher=Kosova Protestant Evangelical Church }}</ref>
==See also==
*[[Religion in Albania]] *[[Christianity in Albania]]
==References== {{reflist}}
== Further reading == *Young, David. ''Lëvizja protestante midis shqiptarëve, 1908-1991''. Prishtina: TENDA, 2011.
{{Europe topic|Protestantism in}}
[[Category:Christianity in Albania]] [[Category:Protestantism by country|Albania]]
{{Albania-stub}} {{Christianity-stub}}

{{NSA surveillance|0}} '''Ragtime''' or RAGTIME is the code name of four secret surveillance programs conducted by the [[National Security Agency]] (NSA) of the United States. These programs date back to at least 2002<ref name=wapo1>[https://apps.washingtonpost.com/g/page/national/nsa-report-on-privacy-violations-in-the-first-quarter-of-2012/395/ NSA report on privacy violations in the first quarter of 2012], The Washington Post, August 16, 2013, p. 12.</ref> and were revealed in March 2013 in the book ''Deep State: Inside the Government Secrecy Industry'', by [[Marc Ambinder]] and D.B. Grady.
These special programs are conducted under the code name RAGTIME (also abbreviated as RT), and are divided into several subcomponents. It's said that about fifty companies have provided data to this domestic collection program.
RAGTIME consists of four parts: RAGTIME-A, RAGTIME-B, RAGTIME-C, and RAGTIME-P.<ref>Shane Harris, [http://www.washingtonian.com/blogs/dead_drop/surveillance-state/ragtime-codename-of-nsas-secret-domestic-intelligence-program-revealed-in-new-book.php Ragtime: Code name of NSA’s Secret Domestic Intelligence Program Revealed in New Book], February 27, 2013 </ref>
According to the book ''Deep State'', only about three dozen NSA officials have access to RAGTIME's intercept data on domestic counter-terrorism collection, though outside the agency some 1000 people have knowledge of the program's details. Internally, the NSA has a compliance staff of about four or five people to ensure the program stays within laws and regulations.<ref>[http://www.slate.com/blogs/future_tense/2013/02/28/deep_state_book_uncovers_details_on_ragtime_domestic_surveillance_program.html Details Revealed on Secret U.S. “Ragtime” Domestic Surveillance Program], February 28, 2013</ref>
Under the RAGTIME-P program, the [[FISA court]] and the US Attorney General both certify a slate of approved targets, which include bulk data, like phone call logs and records that can be collected around those targets. Apparently, RAGTIME-P can process as many as 50 different data sets at one time.
All intercepted data go to the NSA headquarters in Fort Meade, Maryland, where a program called [[XKeyscore]] processes them and sending them to different so-called "production lines" that deal with targets, like counterterrorism or specific countries. These processed data are stored in different NSA databases like [[Pinwale|PINWALE]] for internet content and [[MARINA]] for internet metadata, which is generally stored for five years.
Originally, RAGTIME only applied to NSA Establishment FISA data, but in 2002 this was changed and since then the program encompasses both NSA Establishment FISA and FBI FISA data.<ref name=wapo1></ref> According to Marc Ambinder, RAGTIME refers to phonecall and e-mail content intercepted under FISA authority.<ref>[https://twitter.com/marcambinder/statuses/368228547103453185 Twitter message] from August 16, 2013</ref>
== See also == * [[STELLARWIND]] * [[PRISM (surveillance program)|PRISM]]
== External links == * [http://www.washingtonian.com/blogs/dead_drop/surveillance-state/ragtime-codename-of-nsas-secret-domestic-intelligence-program-revealed-in-new-book.php Ragtime: Code name of NSA’s Secret Domestic Intelligence Program Revealed in New Book] * [http://www.schneier.com/blog/archives/2013/03/the_nsas_ragtim.html The NSA's Ragtime Surveillance Program and the Need for Leaks]
== Notes ==
<references />
[[category:National Security Agency]] [[Category:Counter-terrorism in the United States]] [[Category:Code names]] [[Category:Mass surveillance]] [[Category:American secret government programs]]

{{Merge to|Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Ohrid|date=September 2018}} {{Other|Archdiocese of Ohrid (disambiguation)|Archbishopric of Ohrid (disambiguation)}} The '''Archdiocese of Achrida''' (also '''Archdiocese of Ochrida''' or the '''Archdiocese of Acrida''')(Latin: ''Achridanus seu Ochridanus'') was a Roman Catholic diocese located in the town of [[Achrida]], [[Republic of Macedonia|Macedonia]]. It was suppressed in the 1700s.[http://www.catholic-hierarchy.org/diocese/da560.html "Archdiocese of Achrida (Ochrida)"] ''[[Catholic-Hierarchy.org]]''. David M. Cheney. Retrieved March 23, 2016{{Self-published source|date=December 2016}}[http://www.gcatholic.org/dioceses/former/t0052.htm "Titular Metropolitan See of Acrida"] ''GCatholic.org''. Gabriel Chow. Retrieved February 14, 2016 It is now included in the [[Catholic Church]]'s list of [[titular see]]s.''Ánnuario Pontificio 2013'' (Libreria Editrice Vaticana, 2013, {{ISBN|978-88-209-9070-1}}), p. 1010 ==History== *1320: Established as Archdiocese of Achrida *1700: Suppressed as Titular See of Achrida ==Ordinaries== ===Archdiocese of Achrida=== ''Erected: 1320''
''Latin Name: Achridanus''
''Metropolitan See'' *[[Raphael Levacovich|Rafael Levaković]], [[Order of Friars Minor|O.F.M.]] (27 May 1647 – 1650 Died)[http://www.catholic-hierarchy.org/bishop/blevac.html "Archbishop Raphael Levacovich, O.F.M."] ''[[Catholic-Hierarchy.org]]''. David M. Cheney. Retrieved September 27, 2016{{Self-published source|date=December 2016}} *[[Andrea Bogdani]] (Bogadano) (27 Feb 1651 – 6 Mar 1656 Appointed, [[Archbishop of Skopje]]) *[[Franjo Soimirovic]] (Svimirovich), [[Order of Friars Minor|O.F.M.]] (20 Mar 1656 Appointed – ) *[[Andrea Bogdani]] (Bogadano) (18 Dec 1675 – 1677 Resigned) *[[Basilio Matranga]] [[O.S.B.M.]] (7 Oct 1726 – 7 Apr 1748 Died) == See also == *[[Catholic Church in Macedonia]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{coord missing|Macedonia}} {{Subject bar |portal1= Catholicism |portal2= Macedonia}} [[Category:1320 establishments in Europe]] [[Category:Former Roman Catholic dioceses in Europe|Achrida]] [[Category:Catholic titular sees in Europe|Achrida]] [[Category:Catholic Church in the Republic of Macedonia]] [[Category:Archbishops of Ohrid]] [[Category:Ohrid]] [[Category:Eastern Catholic titular sees|Achrida]] {{Europe-RC-diocese-stub}}

{{Infobox diocese |jurisdiction = Diocese |name = Ibiza |latin = Dioecesis Ebusitanus | local = Diocesis de Ibiza ''(es)''
Bisbat d' Eivissa ''(ca)'' |image = EIVISSA 03 (1590953434).jpg |image_size = 230px |caption = [[Ibiza Cathedral]] |country = {{flag|Spain}} |metropolitan = [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Valencia in Spain|Valencia]] |province = [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Valencia Spain|Valencia]] |rite = [[Latin Rite]] |established = |denomination = [[Roman Catholic]] |cathedral = [[Ibiza Cathedral|Cathedral of St Mary in Ibiza]] |cocathedral = |area_km2 = 872 |population = 118,013 |population_as_of = 2006 |catholics = 110,000 |catholics_percent= 93.2 |pope = {{Incumbent pope}} |bishop = [[Vicente Juan Segura]] |metro_archbishop = [[Antonio Cañizares Llovera]] |coadjutor = |auxiliary_bishops= |map = Localització d'Eivissa respecte les Illes Balears.svg |map_caption = The Diocese of Ibiza in blue. |website = [http://www.obispadodeibiza.es/es/index.php Website of the Diocese] }} [[File:Altar-Kathedrale-Ibiza-Stadt.jpg|thumb|View of the altar of the Cathedral]] The '''Roman Catholic Diocese of Ibiza''' ({{lang-la|Ebusitan(us)}}) is a [[diocese]] located in the city of [[Ibiza]] in the [[Ecclesiastical province]] of [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Valencia in Spain|Valencia]] in Spain. ==History== * April 30, 1782: Established as Diocese of Ibiza from the [[Metropolitan Archdiocese of Tarragona]] * 1851: Suppressed to the [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Majorca|Diocese of Majorca]] * 1927: Restored as Apostolic Administration of Ibiza from the Diocese of Majorca * 1949: Promoted as Diocese of Ibiza ==Leadership== * [[Bishop]]s of Ibiza (Roman rite) ** [[Manuel Abad y Lasierra]] (18 Jul 1783 – 28 Sep 1787 ) ** Eustaquio Azara, O.S.B. (7 Apr 1788 – 12 Sep 1794 ) ** Blas Jacobo Beltrán (26 Jun 1805 – 10 Jul 1815 ) ** Felipe González Abarca, O. de M. (22 Jul 1816 – 30 Aug 1829 ) ** Basilio Antonio Carrasco Hernando, O. de M. (26 Mar 1831 – 4 Apr 1852 ) ** Antonio Cardona Riera (2 Feb 1950 – 28 Mar 1960 ) ** Francisco Planas Muntaner (28 Mar 1960 – 10 Sep 1976 ) ** José Gea Escolano (10 Sep 1976 – 15 May 1987 ) ** Manuel Ureña Pastor (8 Jul 1988 – 23 Jul 1991 ) ** Javier Salinas Viñals (26 May 1992 – 5 Sep 1997 ) ** Agustín Cortés Soriano (20 Feb 1998 – 15 Jun 2004) ** [[Vicente Juan Segura]] (22 Jan 2005 – ) ==See also== * [[Roman Catholicism in Spain]] ==Sources== * [http://www.catholic-hierarchy.org/diocese/dibiz.html Catholic Hierarchy] * [http://www.obispadodeibiza.es/ Diocese website] {{coord|38|52|N|1|26|E|source:cawiki_region:ES-IB|display=title}} {{Roman Catholic dioceses in Spain}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ibiza}} [[Category:Roman Catholic dioceses in Spain]] [[Category:Religious organizations established in 1927]] [[Category:Ibiza]] [[Category:Religious organizations established in 1782]] [[Category:1782 establishments in Spain]] {{Spain-stub}} {{Europe-RC-diocese-stub}}

{{no footnotes|date=November 2015}} {{Infobox diocese |jurisdiction = Diocese |name = Keetmanshoop |latin = Dioecesis Keetmanshoopensis |country = {{flag|Namibia}} |metropolitan = [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Windhoek|Windhoek]] |rite = [[Latin Rite]] |cathedral = St Stanislaus Cathedral |cocathedral = |area_km2 = 264,110 |population = 137,675 |population_as_of = 2004 |catholics = 38,356 |catholics_percent= 27.9 |pope = {{Incumbent pope}} |bishop = [[Phillip Pöllitzer]], [[O.M.I.]] |coadjutor = |auxiliary_bishops= }} The '''Roman Catholic Diocese of Keetmanshoop''' ({{lang-la|Keetmanshoopen(sis)}}) is a [[suffragan]] [[diocese]] in the [[Latin rite]] [[Ecclesiastical province]] of the Metropolitan of [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Windhoek|Windhoek]] in [[Namibia]], yet depends on the missionary [[Roman Congregation for the Evangelization of Peoples]].
Its [[cathedral]] episcopal see is {{ill|St. Stanislaus Cathedral|de|St.-Stanislaus-Kathedrale}}, in the city of [[Keetmanshoop]].
== Statistics == As per 2015, it pastorally served 42,570 Catholics (23.6% of 180,000 total population) on 264,110 km² in 11 parishes and 32 missions with 16 priests (3 diocesan, 13 religious), 13 deacons, 65 lay religious (17 brothers, 48 sisters) and 2 seminarists.
== History == * July 7, 1909: Established as '''[[Apostolic Prefecture]] of Great Namaqualand''', on territory split off from the then [[Apostolic Vicariate of Orange River]] in [[South Africa]] * Promoted on July 14, 1930 as '''[[Apostolic Vicariate]] of Great Namaqualand''' * January 13, 1949: Renamed after its see as '''Apostolic Vicariate of Keetmanshoop''' * Promoted on March 14, 1994 as '''Diocese of Keetmanshoop'''
== Ordinaries == (all [[Roman rite]], so far members of a missionary congregation)
;''Apostolic Prefects of Great Namaqualand * Father [[Stanislao von Krolikowski]], [[Oblates of Saint Francis of Sales]] (O.S.F.S.) (born Europe?) (1910 – death 1923) * Fr. Mattia Eder, O.S.F.S. (born Europe?) (1923.03.16 – death 1930)
;''Apostolic Vicars of Great Namaqualand * Bishop [[Joseph Klemann]], O.S.F.S. (born Europe?) (1931.02.24 – retired 1942), [[Titular Bishop]] of [[Drusiliana]] (1931.02.24 – death 1960.03.21) * [[Giacomo Eich]], O.S.F.S. (born Europe?) (1942.11.10 – death 1947.02.04), Titular Bishop of [[Cynopolis in Ægypto]] (1942.04.21 – 1947.02.04), succeeded as former [[Coadjutor Vicar Apostolic]] of Great Namaqualand (1942.04.21 – 1942.11.10)
;''Apostolic Vicars of Keetmanshoop * [[Francis Esser]], O.S.F.S. (born Germany) (1949.01.13 – 1956), Titular Bishop of [[Claneus]] (1949.01.13 – 1962.09.12), next [[Coadjutor Bishop]] of [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Keimoes|Keimoes]] ([[South Africa]]) (1956 – 1962.09.12), succeeding as Bishop of Keimoes (South Africa) (1962.09.12 – death 1966.12.08) * [[Edward Francis Joseph Schlotterback]], O.S.F.S. (born USA) (1956.03.24 – retired 1989.10.02), Titular Bishop of [[Balanea]] (1956.03.24 – death 1994.12.09) **''[[Apostolic Administrator]] Father Ludger G. Holling, O.S.F.S. (born Europe?) (1989 – 1993.05.28), no other prelature * Anthony Chiminello, O.S.F.S. (born Italy) (1993.05.28 – 1994.03.14 ''see below''), Titular Bishop of [[Numana]] (1993.05.28 – 1994.03.14)
;''Suffragan Bishops of Keetmanshoop * [[Anthony Chiminello]], [[O.S.F.S.]] (''see above'' 1994.03.14 – death 2002.11.23) * Phillip Pöllitzer, O.M.I. (born Austria) (2007.05.31 – retired 2017.07.21) * Bishop-elect Willem Christiaans, O.S.F.S. (first native incumbent) (2018.02.07 – ...); no previous prelature.
== See also == * [[List of Catholic dioceses in Namibia]] * [[Roman Catholicism in Namibia]]
== Sources and External links == * [http://www.gcatholic.org/dioceses/diocese/keet0.htm GCatholic.org] * [http://www.catholic-hierarchy.org/diocese/dktmn.html Catholic Hierarchy] * [http://www.rcchurch.na/keetmanshoop/admin.htm Diocese of Keetmanshoop website]
{{coord|26.5772|S|18.1306|E|source:wikidata|display=title}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Keetmanshoop, Roman Catholic diocese}} [[Category:Roman Catholic dioceses in Namibia]] [[Category:Religious organizations established in 1909|Religious organizations established in 1909]] [[Category:Keetmanshoop]] [[Category:Roman Catholic dioceses and prelatures established in the 20th century]]
{{Africa-RC-diocese-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox diocese |jurisdiction = Diocese |name = Laohekou |local = 天主教老河口教区 |latin = Dioecesis Laohocheuvensis |country = {{flag|China}} |metropolitan = [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Hankou|Hankou]] |province = [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Hankou|Hankou]] |rite = [[Latin Rite]] |cathedral = |cocathedral = |area_km2 = 30,000 |population = 2,500,000 |population_as_of = 1950 |catholics = 20,445 |catholics_percent= 0.8 |pope = {{Incumbent pope}} |bishop = [[Sede Vacante]] |metro_archbishop = [[Sede Vacante]] |coadjutor = |auxiliary_bishops= }} The '''Roman Catholic Diocese of Laohekou/Laohokow''' ({{lang-la|Laohocheuven(sis)}}, {{zh|老河口}}) is a [[suffragan]] Latin [[diocese]] in the [[Ecclesiastical province]] of the Metropolitan [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Hankou|Archbishopric of Hankou]] in central [[China]], but depends on the missionary [[Roman Congregation for the Evangelization of Peoples]].
Its episcopal see is located in the city of [[Laohekou]].
No statistics available. The see is vacant (?dormant) since 1966, without any [[Apostolic administrator]].
== History == * Established on 11 September 1870 as '''[[Apostolic Vicariate]] of Northwestern Hupeh''' 湖北西北, on territory split off from the then [[Apostolic Vicariate of Hupeh]] 湖北 * Renamed on 3 December 1924 as '''Apostolic Vicariate of Laohekou''' 老河口 / Laohokow / de Laohokow (Latin) * Lost territory on 25 May 1936 to establish the [[Apostolic Prefecture of Xiangyang]] 襄陽 * Promoted on 11 April 1946 as '''Diocese of Laohekou''' 老河口 / Laohokow / Laohocheuven(sis) (Latin).
==Episcopal ordinaries== (all [[Roman Rite]]; so far European missionary members of Latin congregations) <ref>http://www.gcatholic.org/dioceses/diocese/laoh0.htm GCatholic.org</ref>
;''Apostolic Vicars of Northwestern Hupeh 湖北西北 * Pascal Bili, [[Friars Minor]] (O.F.M.) (born Italy) (1876.11.20 – death 1878.05.12), [[Titular Bishop]] of [[Gratianopolis (Mauretania Caesariensis)|Gratianopolis]] (1876.11.20 – 1878.05.12) * Ezechias Banci, O.F.M. (born Italy) (1879.09.30 – death 1903.10.08), Titular Bishop of [[Halicarnassus]] (1871.05.06 – 1903.10.08), initially as [[Coadjutor Vicar Apostolic]] of Southern Hunan 湖南南境 (1871.05.06 – succession 1879.09.30) * [[Fabiano Landi]], O.F.M. (born Italy)(10 May 1904 – death 30 June 1920), Titular Bishop of [[Tænarum]] (1904.05.10 – 1920.06.30)
;''Apostolic Vicars of Laohekou 老河口 * [[Ermenegildo Ricci]], O.F.M. (born Italy) (21 February 1922 – retired 1929?1930), Titular Bishop of [[Antipyrgos]] (1922.02.21 – death 1931.11.23) *''[[Apostolic Administrator]] Father Alfonso Maria Corrado Ferrani, O.F.M. (born Italy) (18 October 1930 – 27 January 1932 see below'') * Alfonso Maria Corrado Ferrani, O.F.M. (''see above'' 27 January 1932 – see promoted 11 April 1946 ''see below'')
;''Suffragan Bishops of Laohekou 老河口 * [[Alfonso Maria Corrado Ferrani]], O.F.M. (''see above'' 11 April 1946 – death 10 March 1966).
== See also == {{Portal|Christianity in China}} * [[List of Catholic dioceses in China]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
== Sources and external links == * [http://www.gcatholic.org/dioceses/diocese/laoh0.htm GCatholic.org - data for all sections] * [http://www.catholic-hierarchy.org/diocese/dlaoh.html Catholic Hierarchy]

revision.text:
{{For|the collaborative project that focuses on humanizing the Israeli-Palestinian conflict|Yalla (journal)}}
'''Yalla''' ([[Cyrillic]]: ''Ялла;'' pronounced {{IPA-uz|jælˈlæ|}} in Uzbek) is a [[folk rock]] band from [[Uzbekistan]]. They appeared in 1970 and in the 1970s-1980s, were popular all over the [[Soviet Union]] and [[Warsaw Pact]] countries. The most prominent song of Yalla was ''[[Uchquduq]] - three water wells'', and it was once the most popular hit in [[USSR]] in 1980s. They sing in [[Uzbek language|Uzbek]], [[Russian language|Russian]], and occasionally some other languages, such as Arabic, [[German language|German]] and [[Tatar]].
The leader of the band is [[Farrukh Zokirov]]. The members of Yalla are graduates of the [[Ostrovsky Theatrical Art Institute]] and the Ashrafi State Conservatory in Tashkent. They are not Russian but Uzbek, a Turkic nationality from the crossroads of the ancient Silk Road. Their music incorporates traditional ethnic folk tunes and poetry of Uzbekistan and other Central Asian and Middle Eastern cultures, along with contemporary pop and dance influences, into a unique international blend. They perform songs in more than 10 languages, including Arabic, [[Persian language|Persian]], Hindi, Nepalese and French as well as Uzbek and Russian.
Formed in the early 1970s, Yalla has appeared on Soviet national television as well as performing in Moscow and elsewhere in the Soviet Union, and on concert tours in Europe, Africa, Asia and Latin America, including featured appearances at the "Voice of Asia" festival. The Yalla band had some changes at the time of collapse of the Soviet Union. The Immigration of Rustam Ilyasov (musical arranger and bass guitar) to the United States and independence of Uzbekistan made Yalla change their songs more local. Some new hits came out, such as ''Uzbekistan'', ''Bez lubimyh glaz'' and some more. Yalla invited a dancer Roza Abdulhairiva to make a dance show mixed with singing. Yalla has invited Tolkin Isakov who was a percussion teacher at the Tashkent State Conservatory. He replaced Rustam Ilyasov. Percussionist Ibragim Aliev was an addition to Yalla with a skillful performance on Uzbek national percussion instruments. It was another pick of Yalla for few years (1994–1999).
==References== * {{ru icon}} [http://www.centrasia.ru/newsA.php4?st=1152584700 Фарух Закиров ("Ялла"): «Нам просто хотелось показать миру, что есть такая уникальная культура - Узбекистан» (интервью)] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mQnpzY-PYcQ Yalla "Uchkuduk"] * [https://www.discogs.com/artist/475301-Ялла Yalla - Band] {{Authority control}} [[Category:Uzbekistani rock music groups]] [[Category:Musical groups established in 1970]] [[Category:Soviet vocal-instrumental ensembles]]
{{Asia-band-stub}} {{Uzbekistan-stub}} Tolkin isakov bass guitar arranger
